MDSC702
Notes
Advanced Research Methods, Design and Data Analysis, is a 15 credit module that can be taken as a stand alone module for students with a solid grounding and experience of Research Methods. This module is an adapted and advanced revised version of the 20 Credit "Research Methods Online" and is suitable for all health care professionals and social scientists.

This module builds on MDSC701 (Introduction to Research Methods – developing core skills), and is also designed as a module for those with previous research methods knowledge wishing to progress their skills and for those planning to complete a work-based project/dissertation.

NB - Please see separately forwarded summary sheet addressing feedback from the committee.

Overview

Overview
This advanced module provides an opportunity to students to further develop their understanding of the research process, engaging research design support services, complex multi-variate design and analysis, and the regulatory frameworks to ensure appropriate governance and quality in research. The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks.

This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Students will need to opt into one of the delivery patterns prior to starting the module.

The module is structured with seven weeks teaching activity using lectures and small group work. The staff will deliver the e-lectures in a way that promotes active learning, by using a “sliced” approach where activities (questions, critical reflection) punctuate the presentation. Materials covered within lectures are consolidated through small group work, where students will work in dedicated learning sets to address topics for wider discussion amongst the larger group.

The summative assessment will employ the knowledge and critical skills developed over the course of the module, through the development of a research study protocol. This assessment strategy will ensure that students have the opportunity to demonstrate advanced skills within the research process, and provides students with the opportunity to focus on areas of interest specific to their academic/clinical practice and potentially support completion of a Masters degree.

The module content and format has been designed to widen national and international participation, to increase numbers and viability.
Educational Aims
The aims and subsequent learning outcomes have been developed using a knowledge, clinical/research skills, learner development and professional behaviour format, commensurate with the philosophical hallmarks outlined in Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Commensurate with Masters/Level 7 study, this module aims to;
•facilitate a critical understanding of structured and supported approaches to the development, synthesis and application of research evidence;
•develop the student’s ability to appraise and evaluate advanced approaches within qualitative and quantitative research design and analysis;
•apply the knowledge and skills developed over the module to formulate research questions and corresponding methods and methodologies.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will enable students to further develop and apply their understanding of research. The module will enhance students ability to appraise the design, development, process and analysis of research within health and social science, to critically apply and develop high quality research proposals in a considered and structurally sound approach commensurate with Masters / Level 7 study.

The module is aimed at those who have either completed MDSC701 (Introduction to Research Methods) or have a solid grounding in the basics of research. The module will introduce and explore use and support of Clinical Trials centres and Research Design Support services in the development of advanced study design (e.g. clinical trials, complex interventions). The module will also critique the theory and application of qualitative and quantitative study design and data analysis. The module will equip students with the necessary knowledge and skills to complete a large-scale dissertation project that would be required for a Master’s award, and provide a grounding in advanced research skills, such as those required to successfully submit for research funding.

The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks and demonstrates active learning and authentic assessment, designed to help students gain greater confidence in advanced approaches to research, and enable students to critique and develop research in their own area of practice

The module will have a flexible approach, and will be delivered; online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Delivery will be supported by lectures, audiovisual presentations, quizzes and case-based interactive discussion boards and tutorials.

There is two part summative assessment within this module:

1. Presentation - Study Protocol Critique: Students will present and critique an outline study protocol. (15 Minute Presentation).

2. Study Protocol: Students will develop a robust project protocol amenable for a Masters level project. (2,000 words).

The assessments can be tailored to focus on the students area of interest and area of speciality.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks. The syllabus is structured to ensure that current research and thinking supports the development of a critical understanding of research methods; that students are active learners and engage with the material and teaching team to direct their learning ;and participate in assessments that are contextualised for their professional development.

The syllabus incorporates the following key areas:

-The Systematic Review: SR's and Evidence Based Practice; Developing s SR; Cochrane; LRiG.

-Research Design: Clinical Trials Centres; Study Registration; Research Design Services; Patient and Public involvement; Research Collaborations.

-Advanced approaches to Quantitative research design and analysis: Multivariate Analysis techniques; Statistical Models/Modelling; Time Series Analysis.

-Advanced approaches to Qualitative research design and analysis: The theoretical underpinnings qualitative enquiry; Qualitative Study Design; Analysing Qualitative Data.

-Health Economics: Public Health; Costs and Resource Allocation; QALYs; Principles in Health Economic Evaluation.

-Research Approvals: R&D, Institutional Review Boards; National Research Ethics frameworks.

-Writing for funding: Research Funders (Research Councils; NIHR; International); Core principles of Grant Writing.

The syllabus is actioned through the release of weekly online lectures, addressing the core content and learning objectives of theme for the week.

Lectures: are presented in a "sliced" format - where questions /reflection points are integrated, and students are required to address the activities outlined. For example, during a lecture students may be asked to identify the strengths and limitations of an 'evidence based approach' to practice - pause the lecture whilst they note their thoughts (and findings from internet searches) - and contract their thoughts with those subsequently presented in the lecture.

Group Work: The learning points addressed in the Lectures will form part of the core activity within the online group learning (Learning Sets n=6-8) following the online lecture. Here, students will reflect on identified reading, linked videos and prompted questions relating to the weekly theme. Students will post thoughts, reflections and findings on a discussion board within the VLE, which is supported/moderated daily by the teaching staff. A weekly rotating student chair will be appointed to drive the discussion and report back from the group, to the wider class.

Tutorials: Students are able to access tutorial support in relation to the module content. Equally, learning sets can set up a group tutorial as required/needed to discuss core content.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. The module uses a blend of video lectures, asynchronous discussion boards, and tutorials to progressively build students understanding of a range of research knowledge and practical skills for research.

Sliced Lectures
Topics within the syllabus are introduced with weekly pre-recorded sliced lectures (where questions are asked within the lecture presentation and students are asked to reflect and address points within the presentation). (14 Hours)

Learning Sets
Following the weekly Lecture, the use of tutorials or discussion boards is used to post questions and practical tasks to reflect and engage with. Students will be split into active learning sets (minimum 6, maximum 8) to engage with the discussion question. This activity can take place asynchronously or synchronously according to the demands/opportunities within the activities and learning set (this approach ensures active learning and participation in either an on-line or face to face environment; it also addresses connectedness and personal responsibility for learning). Discussion tasks will focus on developing critical understanding of elements within the research process, such as the design and validation of a study questionnaire, or observing and practicing interview technique. For all students, one member from the learning set (on a rotational basis) will post the findings on a module-wide discussion board, where students can further review, analyse and provide constructive critical comment. (35 Hours)

Supervision
To enable student to structure and focus their learning and structure appropriate assessments, 1-1 supervision is provided. (1.5 hours). Group supervision sessions will complement the above (2.5 hours).

Self-Directed Learning
Students will be required to access directed and supplementary material on a week-by-week basis, aligned to the subject being addressed each week. This information will be presented within the VLE, such as directed/suggested reading material to support the online lecture material and/or group learning activities. The students will also direct their learning to further material pertinent to their particular area of interest (academic/professional) in order to support assessment activities. (97 Hours)

The curriculum for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks:

Research Connected Teaching
The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of basic and clinical sciences with research. The module will provide students with the highest quality active learning experience, through instruction and support of academic staff from across the Faculty. This will ensure teaching is informed by research and best practice evidence, integrating approaches and examples from research practice to promote knowledge and skills development.

Active Learning
The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, creating active learning and supporting confidence. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process, facilitated through the practical experience of reviewing and making sense of data in both qualitative and qualitative forms. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process.

Authentic Assessment
Within the Assessment strategy, students will apply the learning engaged through the module to develop and critically review a research proposal within their own field of practice. Additionally, this assessment activity will prepare students who will progress to completing a Masters Dissertation / Research Project

Confidence
The teaching syllabus designed to equip students with confidence in the knowledge and skills required to critically review their knowledge base and apply this to research practice.The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, active learning and supporting confidence.

Digital Fluency
The module uses digital platform for communication with the students learning sets, and digital platforms to accumulate and examine the current evidence base. Supervisors will guide the students through the preparation for: research, planning, safety assessment, execution of the research and writing up of the research project proposal in a research report format.

Global Citizenship
Content will be taught by teaching faculty drawn from existing national and international collaborations, who will promote a global perspective on their research within their area.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The Assessment Strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, Attributes, and Hallmarks. In particular, the module has been designed to include (authentic) assessment that is meaningful for the students professional/future professional role, and for further progress in Masters/Level 7 studies (preparing for Maters/Level 7 Dissertation/Research).

The Assessments will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their research knowledge and skills to develop and defend a research protocol, such as would be required for a Masters / Level 7 dissertation / project.

There is a two part single summative assessment within this module:

1. Presentation - Study Protocol Critique: Students will present their outline study protocol, providing a balanced and informed critique of the proposal, highlighting the strengths and weaknesses of a range of potential approaches to address their research question(s), and articulating clearly the supporting rationale for the approach selected. (15 Minute Presentation).

2. Study Protocol: Development of a project protocol, such as a systematic review or empirical research study, amenable for a Masters level project and of a standard suitable for publication in a peer reviewed journal within the students speciality (e.g. BMJ Open). (2,000 words).

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module, which will prepare them for designing and defending a study protocol. For both elements of the assessment, students will need to critically review and apply the strengths and weaknesses inherent in different study designs, and understand the purpose and assumptions that can be made from the analysis of associated data: students will have opportunities to explore and examine this in the targeted group work and subsequent discussion fora. In developing their study protocol, students will be familiar with and align study design within frameworks that will enable appropriate registration (if required), approval processes (R&D, Ethics, HRA) and reporting (https://www.equator-network.org/).

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Developing research questions and associated study protocols are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of Authentic Assessment(Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Students will be able to apply and critique the frameworks for classifying "evidence" and evaluate the systematic approaches to evidence synthesis.
 M2 Students will be able to apply and critically evaluate complex approaches in quantitative research design and analysis.
 M3 Students will be able to apply and critically appraise the theoretical underpinnings and approaches to qualitative research study design and data analysis.
 M4 Students will be able to critically appraise the professional, social, ethical and legal frameworks for research

The module will provide students with the highest quality active learning experience, through instruction and support of academic staff from across the Faculty. This will ensure teaching is informed by research and best practice evidence, integrating approaches and examples from research practice to promote knowledge and skills development.

Active Learning
The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, creating active learning and supporting confidence. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process, facilitated through the practical experience of reviewing and making sense of data in both qualitative and qualitative forms. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process.

Authentic Assessment
Within the Assessment strategy, students will apply the learning engaged through the module to develop and critically review a research proposal within their own field of practice. Additionally, this assessment activity will prepare students who will progress to completing a Masters Dissertation / Research Project

Confidence
The teaching syllabus designed to equip students with confidence in the knowledge and skills required to critically review their knowledge base and apply this to research practice.The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, active learning and supporting confidence.

Digital Fluency
The module uses digital platform for communication with the students learning sets, and digital platforms to accumulate and examine the current evidence base. Supervisors will guide the students through the preparation for: research, planning, safety assessment, execution of the research and writing up of the research project proposal in a research report format.

Global Citizenship
Content will be taught by teaching faculty drawn from existing national and international collaborations, who will promote a global perspective on their research within their area.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The Assessment Strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, Attributes, and Hallmarks. In particular, the module has been designed to include (authentic) assessment that is meaningful for the students professional/future professional role, and for further progress in Masters/Level 7 studies (preparing for Maters/Level 7 Dissertation/Research).

The Assessments will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their research knowledge and skills to develop and defend a research protocol, such as would be required for a Masters / Level 7 dissertation / project.

There is a two part single summative assessment within this module:

1. Presentation - Study Protocol Critique: Students will present their outline study protocol, providing a balanced and informed critique of the proposal, highlighting the strengths and weaknesses of a range of potential approaches to address their research question(s), and articulating clearly the supporting rationale for the approach selected. (15 Minute Presentation).

2. Study Protocol: Development of a project protocol, such as a systematic review or empirical research study, amenable for a Masters level project and of a standard suitable for publication in a peer reviewed journal within the students speciality (e.g. BMJ Open). (2,000 words).

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module, which will prepare them for designing and defending a study protocol. For both elements of the assessment, students will need to critically review and apply the strengths and weaknesses inherent in different study designs, and understand the purpose and assumptions that can be made from the analysis of associated data: students will have opportunities to explore and examine this in the targeted group work and subsequent discussion fora. In developing their study protocol, students will be familiar with and align study design within frameworks that will enable appropriate registration (if required), approval processes (R&D, Ethics, HRA) and reporting (https://www.equator-network.org/).

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Developing research questions and associated study protocols are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of Authentic Assessment(Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

MDSC702
Notes
Advanced Research Methods, Design and Data Analysis, is a 15 credit module that can be taken as a stand alone module for students with a solid grounding and experience of Research Methods. This module is an adapted and advanced revised version of the 20 Credit "Research Methods Online" and is suitable for all health care professionals and social scientists.

This module builds on MDSC701 (Introduction to Research Methods – developing core skills), and is also designed as a module for those with previous research methods knowledge wishing to progress their skills and for those planning to complete a work-based project/dissertation.

NB - Please see separately forwarded summary sheet addressing feedback from the committee.

Overview

Overview
This advanced module provides an opportunity to students to further develop their understanding of the research process, engaging research design support services, complex multi-variate design and analysis, and the regulatory frameworks to ensure appropriate governance and quality in research. The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks.

This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Students will need to opt into one of the delivery patterns prior to starting the module.

The module is structured with seven weeks teaching activity using lectures and small group work. The staff will deliver the e-lectures in a way that promotes active learning, by using a “sliced” approach where activities (questions, critical reflection) punctuate the presentation. Materials covered within lectures are consolidated through small group work, where students will work in dedicated learning sets to address topics for wider discussion amongst the larger group.

The summative assessment will employ the knowledge and critical skills developed over the course of the module, through the development of a research study protocol. This assessment strategy will ensure that students have the opportunity to demonstrate advanced skills within the research process, and provides students with the opportunity to focus on areas of interest specific to their academic/clinical practice and potentially support completion of a Masters degree.

The module content and format has been designed to widen national and international participation, to increase numbers and viability.
Educational Aims
The aims and subsequent learning outcomes have been developed using a knowledge, clinical/research skills, learner development and professional behaviour format, commensurate with the philosophical hallmarks outlined in Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Commensurate with Masters/Level 7 study, this module aims to;
•facilitate a critical understanding of structured and supported approaches to the development, synthesis and application of research evidence;
•develop the student’s ability to appraise and evaluate advanced approaches within qualitative and quantitative research design and analysis;
•apply the knowledge and skills developed over the module to formulate research questions and corresponding methods and methodologies.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will enable students to further develop and apply their understanding of research. The module will enhance students ability to appraise the design, development, process and analysis of research within health and social science, to critically apply and develop high quality research proposals in a considered and structurally sound approach commensurate with Masters / Level 7 study.

The module is aimed at those who have either completed MDSC701 (Introduction to Research Methods) or have a solid grounding in the basics of research. The module will introduce and explore use and support of Clinical Trials centres and Research Design Support services in the development of advanced study design (e.g. clinical trials, complex interventions). The module will also critique the theory and application of qualitative and quantitative study design and data analysis. The module will equip students with the necessary knowledge and skills to complete a large-scale dissertation project that would be required for a Master’s award, and provide a grounding in advanced research skills, such as those required to successfully submit for research funding.

The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks and demonstrates active learning and authentic assessment, designed to help students gain greater confidence in advanced approaches to research, and enable students to critique and develop research in their own area of practice

The module will have a flexible approach, and will be delivered; online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Delivery will be supported by lectures, audiovisual presentations, quizzes and case-based interactive discussion boards and tutorials.

There is two part summative assessment within this module:

1. Presentation - Study Protocol Critique: Students will present and critique an outline study protocol. (15 Minute Presentation).

2. Study Protocol: Students will develop a robust project protocol amenable for a Masters level project. (2,000 words).

The assessments can be tailored to focus on the students area of interest and area of speciality.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks. The syllabus is structured to ensure that current research and thinking supports the development of a critical understanding of research methods; that students are active learners and engage with the material and teaching team to direct their learning ;and participate in assessments that are contextualised for their professional development.

The syllabus incorporates the following key areas:

-The Systematic Review: SR's and Evidence Based Practice; Developing s SR; Cochrane; LRiG.

-Research Design: Clinical Trials Centres; Study Registration; Research Design Services; Patient and Public involvement; Research Collaborations.

-Advanced approaches to Quantitative research design and analysis: Multivariate Analysis techniques; Statistical Models/Modelling; Time Series Analysis.

-Advanced approaches to Qualitative research design and analysis: The theoretical underpinnings qualitative enquiry; Qualitative Study Design; Analysing Qualitative Data.

-Health Economics: Public Health; Costs and Resource Allocation; QALYs; Principles in Health Economic Evaluation.

-Research Approvals: R&D, Institutional Review Boards; National Research Ethics frameworks.

-Writing for funding: Research Funders (Research Councils; NIHR; International); Core principles of Grant Writing.

The syllabus is actioned through the release of weekly online lectures, addressing the core content and learning objectives of theme for the week.

Lectures: are presented in a "sliced" format - where questions /reflection points are integrated, and students are required to address the activities outlined. For example, during a lecture students may be asked to identify the strengths and limitations of an 'evidence based approach' to practice - pause the lecture whilst they note their thoughts (and findings from internet searches) - and contract their thoughts with those subsequently presented in the lecture.

Group Work: The learning points addressed in the Lectures will form part of the core activity within the online group learning (Learning Sets n=6-8) following the online lecture. Here, students will reflect on identified reading, linked videos and prompted questions relating to the weekly theme. Students will post thoughts, reflections and findings on a discussion board within the VLE, which is supported/moderated daily by the teaching staff. A weekly rotating student chair will be appointed to drive the discussion and report back from the group, to the wider class.

Tutorials: Students are able to access tutorial support in relation to the module content. Equally, learning sets can set up a group tutorial as required/needed to discuss core content.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. The module uses a blend of video lectures, asynchronous discussion boards, and tutorials to progressively build students understanding of a range of research knowledge and practical skills for research.

Sliced Lectures
Topics within the syllabus are introduced with weekly pre-recorded sliced lectures (where questions are asked within the lecture presentation and students are asked to reflect and address points within the presentation). (14 Hours)

Learning Sets
Following the weekly Lecture, the use of tutorials or discussion boards is used to post questions and practical tasks to reflect and engage with. Students will be split into active learning sets (minimum 6, maximum 8) to engage with the discussion question. This activity can take place asynchronously or synchronously according to the demands/opportunities within the activities and learning set (this approach ensures active learning and participation in either an on-line or face to face environment; it also addresses connectedness and personal responsibility for learning). Discussion tasks will focus on developing critical understanding of elements within the research process, such as the design and validation of a study questionnaire, or observing and practicing interview technique. For all students, one member from the learning set (on a rotational basis) will post the findings on a module-wide discussion board, where students can further review, analyse and provide constructive critical comment. (35 Hours)

Supervision
To enable student to structure and focus their learning and structure appropriate assessments, 1-1 supervision is provided. (1.5 hours). Group supervision sessions will complement the above (2.5 hours).

Self-Directed Learning
Students will be required to access directed and supplementary material on a week-by-week basis, aligned to the subject being addressed each week. This information will be presented within the VLE, such as directed/suggested reading material to support the online lecture material and/or group learning activities. The students will also direct their learning to further material pertinent to their particular area of interest (academic/professional) in order to support assessment activities. (97 Hours)

The curriculum for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks:

Research Connected Teaching
The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of basic and clinical sciences with research. The module will provide students with the highest quality active learning experience, through instruction and support of academic staff from across the Faculty. This will ensure teaching is informed by research and best practice evidence, integrating approaches and examples from research practice to promote knowledge and skills development.

The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process.

Additionally, this assessment activity will prepare students who will progress to completing a Masters Dissertation / Research Project

The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

(15 Minute Presentation).

2. Study Protocol: Development of a project protocol, such as a systematic review or empirical research study, amenable for a Masters level project and of a standard suitable for publication in a peer reviewed journal within the students speciality (e.g. BMJ Open). (2,000 words).

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module, which will prepare them for designing and defending a study protocol. For both elements of the assessment, students will need to critically review and apply the strengths and weaknesses inherent in different study designs, and understand the purpose and assumptions that can be made from the analysis of associated data: students will have opportunities to explore and examine this in the targeted group work and subsequent discussion fora. In developing their study protocol, students will be familiar with and align study design within frameworks that will enable appropriate registration (if required), approval processes (R&D, Ethics, HRA) and reporting (https://www.equator-network.org/).

MDSC702
Notes
Advanced Research Methods, Design and Data Analysis, is a 15 credit module that can be taken as a stand alone module for students with a solid grounding and experience of Research Methods. This module is an adapted and advanced revised version of the 20 Credit "Research Methods Online" and is suitable for all health care professionals and social scientists.

This module builds on MDSC701 (Introduction to Research Methods – developing core skills), and is also designed as a module for those with previous research methods knowledge wishing to progress their skills and for those planning to complete a work-based project/dissertation.

NB - Please see separately forwarded summary sheet addressing feedback from the committee.

Overview

Overview
This advanced module provides an opportunity to students to further develop their understanding of the research process, engaging research design support services, complex multi-variate design and analysis, and the regulatory frameworks to ensure appropriate governance and quality in research. The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks.

This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Students will need to opt into one of the delivery patterns prior to starting the module.

The module is structured with seven weeks teaching activity using lectures and small group work. The staff will deliver the e-lectures in a way that promotes active learning, by using a “sliced” approach where activities (questions, critical reflection) punctuate the presentation. Materials covered within lectures are consolidated through small group work, where students will work in dedicated learning sets to address topics for wider discussion amongst the larger group.

The summative assessment will employ the knowledge and critical skills developed over the course of the module, through the development of a research study protocol. This assessment strategy will ensure that students have the opportunity to demonstrate advanced skills within the research process, and provides students with the opportunity to focus on areas of interest specific to their academic/clinical practice and potentially support completion of a Masters degree.

The module content and format has been designed to widen national and international participation, to increase numbers and viability.
Educational Aims
The aims and subsequent learning outcomes have been developed using a knowledge, clinical/research skills, learner development and professional behaviour format, commensurate with the philosophical hallmarks outlined in Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Commensurate with Masters/Level 7 study, this module aims to;
•facilitate a critical understanding of structured and supported approaches to the development, synthesis and application of research evidence;
•develop the student’s ability to appraise and evaluate advanced approaches within qualitative and quantitative research design and analysis;
•apply the knowledge and skills developed over the module to formulate research questions and corresponding methods and methodologies.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will enable students to further develop and apply their understanding of research. The module will enhance students ability to appraise the design, development, process and analysis of research within health and social science, to critically apply and develop high quality research proposals in a considered and structurally sound approach commensurate with Masters / Level 7 study.

The module is aimed at those who have either completed MDSC701 (Introduction to Research Methods) or have a solid grounding in the basics of research. The module will introduce and explore use and support of Clinical Trials centres and Research Design Support services in the development of advanced study design (e.g. clinical trials, complex interventions). The module will also critique the theory and application of qualitative and quantitative study design and data analysis. The module will equip students with the necessary knowledge and skills to complete a large-scale dissertation project that would be required for a Master’s award, and provide a grounding in advanced research skills, such as those required to successfully submit for research funding.

The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks and demonstrates active learning and authentic assessment, designed to help students gain greater confidence in advanced approaches to research, and enable students to critique and develop research in their own area of practice

The module will have a flexible approach, and will be delivered; online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Delivery will be supported by lectures, audiovisual presentations, quizzes and case-based interactive discussion boards and tutorials.

There is two part summative assessment within this module:

1. Presentation - Study Protocol Critique: Students will present and critique an outline study protocol. (15 Minute Presentation).

2. Study Protocol: Students will develop a robust project protocol amenable for a Masters level project. (2,000 words).

The assessments can be tailored to focus on the students area of interest and area of speciality.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks. The syllabus is structured to ensure that current research and thinking supports the development of a critical understanding of research methods; that students are active learners and engage with the material and teaching team to direct their learning ;and participate in assessments that are contextualised for their professional development.

The syllabus incorporates the following key areas:

-The Systematic Review: SR's and Evidence Based Practice; Developing s SR; Cochrane; LRiG.

-Research Design: Clinical Trials Centres; Study Registration; Research Design Services; Patient and Public involvement; Research Collaborations.

-Advanced approaches to Quantitative research design and analysis: Multivariate Analysis techniques; Statistical Models/Modelling; Time Series Analysis.

-Advanced approaches to Qualitative research design and analysis: The theoretical underpinnings qualitative enquiry; Qualitative Study Design; Analysing Qualitative Data.

-Health Economics: Public Health; Costs and Resource Allocation; QALYs; Principles in Health Economic Evaluation.

-Research Approvals: R&D, Institutional Review Boards; National Research Ethics frameworks.

-Writing for funding: Research Funders (Research Councils; NIHR; International); Core principles of Grant Writing.

The syllabus is actioned through the release of weekly online lectures, addressing the core content and learning objectives of theme for the week.

Lectures: are presented in a "sliced" format - where questions /reflection points are integrated, and students are required to address the activities outlined. For example, during a lecture students may be asked to identify the strengths and limitations of an 'evidence based approach' to practice - pause the lecture whilst they note their thoughts (and findings from internet searches) - and contract their thoughts with those subsequently presented in the lecture.

Group Work: The learning points addressed in the Lectures will form part of the core activity within the online group learning (Learning Sets n=6-8) following the online lecture. Here, students will reflect on identified reading, linked videos and prompted questions relating to the weekly theme. Students will post thoughts, reflections and findings on a discussion board within the VLE, which is supported/moderated daily by the teaching staff. A weekly rotating student chair will be appointed to drive the discussion and report back from the group, to the wider class.

Tutorials: Students are able to access tutorial support in relation to the module content. Equally, learning sets can set up a group tutorial as required/needed to discuss core content.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. The module uses a blend of video lectures, asynchronous discussion boards, and tutorials to progressively build students understanding of a range of research knowledge and practical skills for research.

Sliced Lectures
Topics within the syllabus are introduced with weekly pre-recorded sliced lectures (where questions are asked within the lecture presentation and students are asked to reflect and address points within the presentation). (14 Hours)

Learning Sets
Following the weekly Lecture, the use of tutorials or discussion boards is used to post questions and practical tasks to reflect and engage with. Students will be split into active learning sets (minimum 6, maximum 8) to engage with the discussion question. This activity can take place asynchronously or synchronously according to the demands/opportunities within the activities and learning set (this approach ensures active learning and participation in either an on-line or face to face environment; it also addresses connectedness and personal responsibility for learning). Discussion tasks will focus on developing critical understanding of elements within the research process, such as the design and validation of a study questionnaire, or observing and practicing interview technique. For all students, one member from the learning set (on a rotational basis) will post the findings on a module-wide discussion board, where students can further review, analyse and provide constructive critical comment. (35 Hours)

Supervision
To enable student to structure and focus their learning and structure appropriate assessments, 1-1 supervision is provided. (1.5 hours). Group supervision sessions will complement the above (2.5 hours).

Self-Directed Learning
Students will be required to access directed and supplementary material on a week-by-week basis, aligned to the subject being addressed each week. This information will be presented within the VLE, such as directed/suggested reading material to support the online lecture material and/or group learning activities. The students will also direct their learning to further material pertinent to their particular area of interest (academic/professional) in order to support assessment activities. (97 Hours)

The curriculum for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks:

Research Connected Teaching
The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of basic and clinical sciences with research. The module will provide students with the highest quality active learning experience, through instruction and support of academic staff from across the Faculty. This will ensure teaching is informed by research and best practice evidence, integrating approaches and examples from research practice to promote knowledge and skills development.

Active Learning
The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, creating active learning and supporting confidence. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process, facilitated through the practical experience of reviewing and making sense of data in both qualitative and qualitative forms. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process.

Authentic Assessment
Within the Assessment strategy, students will apply the learning engaged through the module to develop and critically review a research proposal within their own field of practice. Additionally, this assessment activity will prepare students who will progress to completing a Masters Dissertation / Research Project

Confidence
The teaching syllabus designed to equip students with confidence in the knowledge and skills required to critically review their knowledge base and apply this to research practice.The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, active learning and supporting confidence.

Digital Fluency
The module uses digital platform for communication with the students learning sets, and digital platforms to accumulate and examine the current evidence base. Supervisors will guide the students through the preparation for: research, planning, safety assessment, execution of the research and writing up of the research project proposal in a research report format.

Global Citizenship
Content will be taught by teaching faculty drawn from existing national and international collaborations, who will promote a global perspective on their research within their area.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The Assessment Strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, Attributes, and Hallmarks. In particular, the module has been designed to include (authentic) assessment that is meaningful for the students professional/future professional role, and for further progress in Masters/Level 7 studies (preparing for Maters/Level 7 Dissertation/Research).

The Assessments will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their research knowledge and skills to develop and defend a research protocol, such as would be required for a Masters / Level 7 dissertation / project.

There is a two part single summative assessment within this module:

1. Presentation - Study Protocol Critique: Students will present their outline study protocol, providing a balanced and informed critique of the proposal, highlighting the strengths and weaknesses of a range of potential approaches to address their research question(s), and articulating clearly the supporting rationale for the approach selected. (15 Minute Presentation).

2. Study Protocol: Development of a project protocol, such as a systematic review or empirical research study, amenable for a Masters level project and of a standard suitable for publication in a peer reviewed journal within the students speciality (e.g. BMJ Open). (2,000 words).

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module, which will prepare them for designing and defending a study protocol. For both elements of the assessment, students will need to critically review and apply the strengths and weaknesses inherent in different study designs, and understand the purpose and assumptions that can be made from the analysis of associated data: students will have opportunities to explore and examine this in the targeted group work and subsequent discussion fora. In developing their study protocol, students will be familiar with and align study design within frameworks that will enable appropriate registration (if required), approval processes (R&D, Ethics, HRA) and reporting (https://www.equator-network.org/).

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Developing research questions and associated study protocols are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of Authentic Assessment(Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Students will be able to apply and critique the frameworks for classifying "evidence" and evaluate the systematic approaches to evidence synthesis.
 M2 Students will be able to apply and critically evaluate complex approaches in quantitative research design and analysis.
 M3 Students will be able to apply and critically appraise the theoretical underpinnings and approaches to qualitative research study design and data analysis.
 M4 Students will be able to critically appraise the professional, social, ethical and legal frameworks for research

Active Learning
The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, creating active learning and supporting confidence. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process, facilitated through the practical experience of reviewing and making sense of data in both qualitative and qualitative forms. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process.

Authentic Assessment
Within the Assessment strategy, students will apply the learning engaged through the module to develop and critically review a research proposal within their own field of practice. Additionally, this assessment activity will prepare students who will progress to completing a Masters Dissertation / Research Project

Confidence
The teaching syllabus designed to equip students with confidence in the knowledge and skills required to critically review their knowledge base and apply this to research practice.The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, active learning and supporting confidence.

Digital Fluency
The module uses digital platform for communication with the students learning sets, and digital platforms to accumulate and examine the current evidence base. Supervisors will guide the students through the preparation for: research, planning, safety assessment, execution of the research and writing up of the research project proposal in a research report format.

Global Citizenship
Content will be taught by teaching faculty drawn from existing national and international collaborations, who will promote a global perspective on their research within their area.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The Assessment Strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, Attributes, and Hallmarks. In particular, the module has been designed to include (authentic) assessment that is meaningful for the students professional/future professional role, and for further progress in Masters/Level 7 studies (preparing for Maters/Level 7 Dissertation/Research).

The Assessments will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their research knowledge and skills to develop and defend a research protocol, such as would be required for a Masters / Level 7 dissertation / project.

There is a two part single summative assessment within this module:

1. Presentation - Study Protocol Critique: Students will present their outline study protocol, providing a balanced and informed critique of the proposal, highlighting the strengths and weaknesses of a range of potential approaches to address their research question(s), and articulating clearly the supporting rationale for the approach selected. (15 Minute Presentation).

2. Study Protocol: Development of a project protocol, such as a systematic review or empirical research study, amenable for a Masters level project and of a standard suitable for publication in a peer reviewed journal within the students speciality (e.g. BMJ Open). (2,000 words).

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module, which will prepare them for designing and defending a study protocol. For both elements of the assessment, students will need to critically review and apply the strengths and weaknesses inherent in different study designs, and understand the purpose and assumptions that can be made from the analysis of associated data: students will have opportunities to explore and examine this in the targeted group work and subsequent discussion fora. In developing their study protocol, students will be familiar with and align study design within frameworks that will enable appropriate registration (if required), approval processes (R&D, Ethics, HRA) and reporting (https://www.equator-network.org/).

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Developing research questions and associated study protocols are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of Authentic Assessment(Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

MDSC702
Notes
Advanced Research Methods, Design and Data Analysis, is a 15 credit module that can be taken as a stand alone module for students with a solid grounding and experience of Research Methods. This module is an adapted and advanced revised version of the 20 Credit "Research Methods Online" and is suitable for all health care professionals and social scientists.

This module builds on MDSC701 (Introduction to Research Methods – developing core skills), and is also designed as a module for those with previous research methods knowledge wishing to progress their skills and for those planning to complete a work-based project/dissertation.

NB - Please see separately forwarded summary sheet addressing feedback from the committee.

Overview

Overview
This advanced module provides an opportunity to students to further develop their understanding of the research process, engaging research design support services, complex multi-variate design and analysis, and the regulatory frameworks to ensure appropriate governance and quality in research. The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks.

This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Students will need to opt into one of the delivery patterns prior to starting the module.

The module is structured with seven weeks teaching activity using lectures and small group work. The staff will deliver the e-lectures in a way that promotes active learning, by using a “sliced” approach where activities (questions, critical reflection) punctuate the presentation. Materials covered within lectures are consolidated through small group work, where students will work in dedicated learning sets to address topics for wider discussion amongst the larger group.

The summative assessment will employ the knowledge and critical skills developed over the course of the module, through the development of a research study protocol. This assessment strategy will ensure that students have the opportunity to demonstrate advanced skills within the research process, and provides students with the opportunity to focus on areas of interest specific to their academic/clinical practice and potentially support completion of a Masters degree.

The module content and format has been designed to widen national and international participation, to increase numbers and viability.
Educational Aims
The aims and subsequent learning outcomes have been developed using a knowledge, clinical/research skills, learner development and professional behaviour format, commensurate with the philosophical hallmarks outlined in Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Commensurate with Masters/Level 7 study, this module aims to;
•facilitate a critical understanding of structured and supported approaches to the development, synthesis and application of research evidence;
•develop the student’s ability to appraise and evaluate advanced approaches within qualitative and quantitative research design and analysis;
•apply the knowledge and skills developed over the module to formulate research questions and corresponding methods and methodologies.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will enable students to further develop and apply their understanding of research. The module will enhance students ability to appraise the design, development, process and analysis of research within health and social science, to critically apply and develop high quality research proposals in a considered and structurally sound approach commensurate with Masters / Level 7 study.

The module is aimed at those who have either completed MDSC701 (Introduction to Research Methods) or have a solid grounding in the basics of research. The module will introduce and explore use and support of Clinical Trials centres and Research Design Support services in the development of advanced study design (e.g. clinical trials, complex interventions). The module will also critique the theory and application of qualitative and quantitative study design and data analysis. The module will equip students with the necessary knowledge and skills to complete a large-scale dissertation project that would be required for a Master’s award, and provide a grounding in advanced research skills, such as those required to successfully submit for research funding.

The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks and demonstrates active learning and authentic assessment, designed to help students gain greater confidence in advanced approaches to research, and enable students to critique and develop research in their own area of practice

The module will have a flexible approach, and will be delivered; online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Delivery will be supported by lectures, audiovisual presentations, quizzes and case-based interactive discussion boards and tutorials.

There is two part summative assessment within this module:

1. Presentation - Study Protocol Critique: Students will present and critique an outline study protocol. (15 Minute Presentation).

2. Study Protocol: Students will develop a robust project protocol amenable for a Masters level project. (2,000 words).

The assessments can be tailored to focus on the students area of interest and area of speciality.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks. The syllabus is structured to ensure that current research and thinking supports the development of a critical understanding of research methods; that students are active learners and engage with the material and teaching team to direct their learning ;and participate in assessments that are contextualised for their professional development.

The syllabus incorporates the following key areas:

-The Systematic Review: SR's and Evidence Based Practice; Developing s SR; Cochrane; LRiG.

-Research Design: Clinical Trials Centres; Study Registration; Research Design Services; Patient and Public involvement; Research Collaborations.

-Advanced approaches to Quantitative research design and analysis: Multivariate Analysis techniques; Statistical Models/Modelling; Time Series Analysis.

-Advanced approaches to Qualitative research design and analysis: The theoretical underpinnings qualitative enquiry; Qualitative Study Design; Analysing Qualitative Data.

-Health Economics: Public Health; Costs and Resource Allocation; QALYs; Principles in Health Economic Evaluation.

-Research Approvals: R&D, Institutional Review Boards; National Research Ethics frameworks.

-Writing for funding: Research Funders (Research Councils; NIHR; International); Core principles of Grant Writing.

The syllabus is actioned through the release of weekly online lectures, addressing the core content and learning objectives of theme for the week.

Lectures: are presented in a "sliced" format - where questions /reflection points are integrated, and students are required to address the activities outlined. For example, during a lecture students may be asked to identify the strengths and limitations of an 'evidence based approach' to practice - pause the lecture whilst they note their thoughts (and findings from internet searches) - and contract their thoughts with those subsequently presented in the lecture.

Group Work: The learning points addressed in the Lectures will form part of the core activity within the online group learning (Learning Sets n=6-8) following the online lecture. Here, students will reflect on identified reading, linked videos and prompted questions relating to the weekly theme. Students will post thoughts, reflections and findings on a discussion board within the VLE, which is supported/moderated daily by the teaching staff. A weekly rotating student chair will be appointed to drive the discussion and report back from the group, to the wider class.

Tutorials: Students are able to access tutorial support in relation to the module content. Equally, learning sets can set up a group tutorial as required/needed to discuss core content.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. The module uses a blend of video lectures, asynchronous discussion boards, and tutorials to progressively build students understanding of a range of research knowledge and practical skills for research.

Sliced Lectures
Topics within the syllabus are introduced with weekly pre-recorded sliced lectures (where questions are asked within the lecture presentation and students are asked to reflect and address points within the presentation). (14 Hours)

Learning Sets
Following the weekly Lecture, the use of tutorials or discussion boards is used to post questions and practical tasks to reflect and engage with. Students will be split into active learning sets (minimum 6, maximum 8) to engage with the discussion question. This activity can take place asynchronously or synchronously according to the demands/opportunities within the activities and learning set (this approach ensures active learning and participation in either an on-line or face to face environment; it also addresses connectedness and personal responsibility for learning). Discussion tasks will focus on developing critical understanding of elements within the research process, such as the design and validation of a study questionnaire, or observing and practicing interview technique. For all students, one member from the learning set (on a rotational basis) will post the findings on a module-wide discussion board, where students can further review, analyse and provide constructive critical comment. (35 Hours)

Supervision
To enable student to structure and focus their learning and structure appropriate assessments, 1-1 supervision is provided. (1.5 hours). Group supervision sessions will complement the above (2.5 hours).

Self-Directed Learning
Students will be required to access directed and supplementary material on a week-by-week basis, aligned to the subject being addressed each week. This information will be presented within the VLE, such as directed/suggested reading material to support the online lecture material and/or group learning activities. The students will also direct their learning to further material pertinent to their particular area of interest (academic/professional) in order to support assessment activities. (97 Hours)

The curriculum for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks:

Research Connected Teaching
The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of basic and clinical sciences with research. The module will provide students with the highest quality active learning experience, through instruction and support of academic staff from across the Faculty. This will ensure teaching is informed by research and best practice evidence, integrating approaches and examples from research practice to promote knowledge and skills development.

Active Learning
The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, creating active learning and supporting confidence. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process, facilitated through the practical experience of reviewing and making sense of data in both qualitative and qualitative forms. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process.

Additionally, this assessment activity will prepare students who will progress to completing a Masters Dissertation / Research Project

The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

(15 Minute Presentation).

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module, which will prepare them for designing and defending a study protocol. For both elements of the assessment, students will need to critically review and apply the strengths and weaknesses inherent in different study designs, and understand the purpose and assumptions that can be made from the analysis of associated data: students will have opportunities to explore and examine this in the targeted group work and subsequent discussion fora.
